citation.article-title: Holophaga foetida gen. nov., sp. nov., a new, homoacetogenic bacterium degrading methoxylated aromatic compounds

p.s: Holophaga (holos Gr. n. entire, whole; phagein Gr. v. to eat; Ho.lo.pha'ga M. L. f. n. eating it all (i.e. both the methyl substituents and the phenolic ring of trimethoxybenzoate))
Cells utilize methyl substituents of methylated aromatic compounds with formation of methylated sulfides if sulfide is present in the medium.
Simultaneous or alternative homoacetogenic metabolism of methyl substituents; degradation of trihydroxybenzenes through the phloroglucinol pathway.
External electron acceptors (sulfate, nitrate) are not reduced.
Phylogenetically, the genus represents a novel line of descent of uncertain affiliation within the domain Bacteria.
A deep rooted branching point within the class Proteobacteria might be confirmed when more sequences of this new lineage are available.
The DNA base composition of the type strain is 62.5 mol% G+C as determined by HPLC.
The type species is Holophaga foetida.
